This call will provide insights into the company’s performance and strategic direction, potentially impacting stakeholders’ understanding of its market positioning and future growth prospects.

More about TruAlt Bioenergy Ltd.

TruAlt Bioenergy Limited, formerly known as TruAlt Energy Limited, is India’s largest ethanol producer by installed capacity and a leading integrated biofuels company. The company is involved in ethanol, compressed bio gas (CBG), and is expanding into second generation (2G) ethanol, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), and allied biochemicals. TruAlt is strategically positioned to leverage India’s growing demand for sustainable fuels and is aligned with government initiatives such as the National Biofuels Policy 2018 and the Ethanol Blending Program.

title: Australia is sitting on potential sustainable fuel industry worth $13 billion a year - The Daily Telegraph
description:
In September, Jim Chalmers and Chris Bowen announced $1.1bn of support to grow more feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
“That would be the right point to announce that there will be a SAF mandate” to support demand, Mr Forshaw said.
“Singapore will derive that economic benefit, not Australia,” Mr Forshaw warned, noting that Singapore already has a massive SAF refining capability.
This year the UK introduced a two per cent SAF mandate.
This masthead put the aviation heavyweights’ concerns to the office of Mr Bowen, who is the climate change and energy minister.
text:
In as little as six months Australia will be at risk of losing the chance to create a $13 billion-a-year industry – unless the Albanese government signals that planes will have to use biofuel, Airbus has warned.

The jet-building giant’s local chief executive Stephen Forshaw told this masthead that without a commitment from Canberra, local crops capable of feeding a new refining sector would instead be “hoovered up” by the likes of Singapore.

In September, Jim Chalmers and Chris Bowen announced $1.1bn of support to grow more feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

At the time, the government said it would consult on the production incentive structure until mid-2026.

“That would be the right point to announce that there will be a SAF mandate” to support demand, Mr Forshaw said.

He suggested beginning with a requirement of just one to two per cent of total consumption, rising to 10 per cent over time.

“We’ve got in the range of another six to 12 months before the window will really start to close on us,” he said, because the feedstock would begin to be “hoovered up”.

“Singapore will derive that economic benefit, not Australia,” Mr Forshaw warned, noting that Singapore already has a massive SAF refining capability.

Right now, no SAF is made in Australia.

Airbus is pushing for a SAF mandate because its business is doomed in the long-term unless its airline customers are able to reduce their carbon footprint. SAF offers the best opportunity.

Research commissioned by Airbus and Qantas has found domestic SAF production has the potential to contribute $13bn in GDP annually by 2040, supporting 13,000 jobs in the feedstock supply chain and another 5000 to construct and run the refining facilities.

Want to read more of the stories you love on one of our state news websites? Click here to sign up for a free trial and access 12 locked articles on web over 12 weeks. Limits and T&Cs apply.

Qantas chief sustainability officer Fiona Messent shared Mr Forshaw’s concerns about the need for action, otherwise “a lot of the feedstock could be exported and tied up overseas rather than realising the economic gains here.”

SAF can be made from sugarcane, which Australia has in abundance. It can also be derived from canola. Already, more than 70 per cent of Australia’s canola is exported to Europe to be turned into SAF.

That biofuel can end up in the wing of a Qantas-branded Airbus departing London Heathrow. This year the UK introduced a two per cent SAF mandate. It will rise to 10 per cent by 2030, which is the same as Qantas’ self-imposed target.

In May, Qantas, Sydney Airport and Ampol combined forces to import nearly two million litres of SAF. It was made using waste cooking oil from restaurants in China.

Ms Messent said a domestic SAF sector was an ideal fit with the Albanese government’s Future Made in Australia agenda.

“It had such a clear economic benefit,” she said.

This masthead put the aviation heavyweights’ concerns to the office of Mr Bowen, who is the climate change and energy minister.

In response a spokeswoman said: “The government will continue engaging with industry on how to make sure Australian liquid fuel users have a fair chance to capture the emissions reduction potential unlocked by low-emission Australian fuels.”

title: Sugar cane farmer calls for biofuel to be made to help them grow and survive into the future
description:
Sugar cane farmer Lawrence Di Bella says that after 20 years of people talking about the potential of a local biofuel sector, the time has come for action.
Mr Di Bella produces about 13,000 tonnes of cane annually outside Ingham, between Townsville and Cairns.
“If we stay with sugar alone we are not going to grow the pie,” Mr Di Bella said.
Sugar cane was one of the best crops for energy conversion, Mr Di Bella said, making it ideal for SAF.
Mr Di Bella lamented that people had been talking about the potential of biofuel in Australia for 20 years.
text:
Sugar cane farmer Lawrence Di Bella says that after 20 years of people talking about the potential of a local biofuel sector, the time has come for action.

Mr Di Bella produces about 13,000 tonnes of cane annually outside Ingham, between Townsville and Cairns.

The qualified agronomist said the industry was currently too reliant on crystal sugar, the price of which had fallen to be barely above the cost of production.

Whenever it sinks below the cost of production, the industry has to wind back operations and go into “survival mode,” he said.

“If we stay with sugar alone we are not going to grow the pie,” Mr Di Bella said.

“Developing a sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) industry is going to allow us to grow that pie,” not just for farmers, but for harvesters and millers,” he added.

Sugar cane was one of the best crops for energy conversion, Mr Di Bella said, making it ideal for SAF.

Want to read more of the stories you love on one of our state news websites? Click here to sign up for a free trial and access 12 locked articles on web over 12 weeks. Limits and T&Cs apply.

Mr Di Bella, 55, said two of his children – Hayden, 25, and Gemma, 17 – want to be part of the future of farming in the region.

SAF would all but cement that future.

Mr Di Bella lamented that people had been talking about the potential of biofuel in Australia for 20 years.

“In Australia we do all the talk and no action,” he said. “It’s time for action now.

“We’ve let everything go offshore. It’s time to do stuff at home.”

Mr Di Bella said he had seen SAF industries first-hand in Brazil and the US, which had been supported by governments through legislation and incentives.

The region’s mayor Ramon Jayo, who is also a cane farmer, said: “The economic reality is that we do need to diversify in the sugar industry. You simply can’t have all your eggs in one basket.”

SAF would be a complementary income stream.

“We can enjoy the benefits of having a multifaceted product,” Mr Jayo said.

This article is part of the Back Australia series, which was supported by Australian Made Campaign, Harvey Norman, Westpac, Bunnings, Coles, TechnologyOne, REA Group, Cadbury, R.M.Williams, Qantas, Vodafone and BHP.

title: Australian Defence Force needs sustainable aviation fuel for national security - The Mercury
description:
The defence force says it wants to source sustainable aviation fuel that has been made entirely in Australia because it will improve the nation’s fuel security.
Defence planning documents highlight the pressing need to lower dependence on foreign crude from the current level of 90 per cent and embrace sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
That opportunity is for Defence to use its sizeable fuel needs to influence the development of a local SAF industry.
Earlier this year, Defence began a trial of SAF at its RAAF base at East Sale, south east of Melbourne.
“We are seeking to source domestically … because that is getting after fuel security,” Director General Fuel Capability Brigadier Mark Baldock told this masthead.
text:
The defence force says it wants to source sustainable aviation fuel that has been made entirely in Australia because it will improve the nation’s fuel security.

Defence planning documents highlight the pressing need to lower dependence on foreign crude from the current level of 90 per cent and embrace sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

As well as cutting carbon emissions, the move would reduce reliance on global supply chains that are increasingly susceptible to disruptions, with a recent strategy paper citing rising “tension in the Indo-Pacific” as one of many potential threats.

That paper also warned that Australia is one of the only nations in the developed world with no minimum reserves of liquid fuels for an emergency and that the country has “struggled” to meet its International Energy Agency 90-day stockpiling commitment.

Struggled is a euphemism – Australia consistently ranks last out of the more than 30 IEA member countries for oil holdings.

Want to read more of the stories you love on one of our state news websites? Click here to sign up for a free trial and access 12 locked articles on web over 12 weeks. Limits and T&Cs apply.

However, Defence has identified an opportunity arising from Australia’s incapability to provide a reliable flow of petroleum-based fuel in the event of supply chain breakdowns.

That opportunity is for Defence to use its sizeable fuel needs to influence the development of a local SAF industry.

Earlier this year, Defence began a trial of SAF at its RAAF base at East Sale, south east of Melbourne.

That SAF was imported. In the future, Defence wants the SAF it buys to be made here.

“We are seeking to source domestically … because that is getting after fuel security,” Director General Fuel Capability Brigadier Mark Baldock told this masthead.

The blend being used in the trial is five per cent SAF. Only the relative high price of SAF is stopping Defence from going higher.

“We have to increase the demand signal to drive the cost down,” Brigadier Baldock said.

At the moment, no SAF is made in Australia. But building work recently began on the first SAF refinery, at Townsville, Queensland.

This article is part of the Back Australia series, which was supported by Australian Made Campaign, Harvey Norman, Westpac, Bunnings, Coles, TechnologyOne, REA Group, Cadbury, R.M.Williams, Qantas, Vodafone and BHP.

title: ESG Fails Goan Filmmakers Once Again: No Goan Film in IFFI's Official Section: Vishal Pai Cacode
description:
Panaji: Not a single Goan film features in the official section of the International Film Festival of India (IFFI) 2025, as per the list uploaded on the festival’s website.
The Goa Film Finance Scheme, which was meant to empower local producers and sustain regional cinema, has become almost dormant.
Many Goan filmmakers have been struggling for years to access financial assistance trapped in endless paperwork, opaque criteria, and official apathy, said Vishal Pai Cacode.
The result is a festival that glitters on the surface but fails to reflect the voices of the land that hosts it, Vishal Pai Cacode said.
Goa’s film community deserves more than tokenism; it deserves opportunity, dignity, and a genuine platform to shine, said Vishal Pai Cacode.
text:
Panaji: Not a single Goan film features in the official section of the International Film Festival of India (IFFI) 2025, as per the list uploaded on the festival’s website. This glaring omission exposes the Entertainment Society of Goa’s (ESG) continuing failure to nurture and promote local filmmakers, a tragic irony in the very land that hosts one of the world’s oldest and most celebrated film festivals, stated former Member of Governing Body of ESG Vishal Pai Cacode.

While crores are being splurged on red carpets, events, and cosmetic spectacles, Goan cinema continues to be starved of even the most basic support. The Goa Film Finance Scheme, which was meant to empower local producers and sustain regional cinema, has become almost dormant. Many Goan filmmakers have been struggling for years to access financial assistance trapped in endless paperwork, opaque criteria, and official apathy, said Vishal Pai Cacode.

Equally alarming is ESG’s failure to create even minimal film-making infrastructure in the state. Despite two decades of IFFI in Goa, there is still no proper editing studio, equipment bank, crane facility, or professional light and sound setup available for local use. The absence of such essential resources forces young filmmakers to rely on private vendors from outside Goa, drastically inflating production costs and discouraging local talent, he said.

Instead of investing in sustainable creative infrastructure and supporting Goan stories, ESG’s focus appears to have shifted entirely toward event management and commission-driven contracts. The result is a festival that glitters on the surface but fails to reflect the voices of the land that hosts it, Vishal Pai Cacode said.

IFFI must once again become a festival of the people and for the artists, not a playground for contractors and commission agents. Goa’s film community deserves more than tokenism; it deserves opportunity, dignity, and a genuine platform to shine, said Vishal Pai Cacode.

title: Driver shares honest reactions after switching to EV for the first time: 'I finally made the plunge'
description:
One driver proudly told the "r/EquinoxEv" subreddit, "I finally made the plunge" and switched to electric vehicles.
A photo of the shiny red 2025 Chevrolet Equinox EV RS shows the driver's stylish transition away from combustion-engine vehicles.
So far, the new EV driver's only minor complaint concerns a potential upgrade for charging their phone inside this model.
According to a 2024 Atlas Public Policy study, EV owners generally save 40-65% on annual fuel costs versus gas-powered vehicle drivers.
Upgrading your HVAC system to a heat pump can boost your solar power savings and help you pocket about $400 a year in energy costs.
text:
One driver proudly told the "r/EquinoxEv" subreddit, "I finally made the plunge" and switched to electric vehicles.

A photo of the shiny red 2025 Chevrolet Equinox EV RS shows the driver's stylish transition away from combustion-engine vehicles.

"Beautiful color. Enjoy your new vehicle," praised one commenter, while another said, "The red looks so good! Congrats. Got my first one in July and love it!"

So far, the new EV driver's only minor complaint concerns a potential upgrade for charging their phone inside this model. They prefer "a modified pad for the Qi charging pad" for their phone, since the rubber insert on the current model is a hindrance. However, they added, "Works great when I remove the rubber insert."

Despite the phone-charging dilemma, the EV owner's transition away from internal combustion engine cars is a healthy choice. Vehicle pollutants such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, particulate matter, ultrafine particles (UFPs), and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) linger in the air through tailpipe exhaust. This increases cancer risk along with respiratory and heart issues, according to the California Air Resources Board.

With zero tailpipe pollution, per the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, and lithium batteries that can be recycled, EV usage can help clear and cool down the air on an overheating planet. Depending on your driving needs, you can even fill up at home and avoid vandalism at charging stations.

Plus, there's the impressive savings. According to a 2024 Atlas Public Policy study, EV owners generally save 40-65% on annual fuel costs versus gas-powered vehicle drivers. Thanks to fewer mechanical components, these green cars also help drivers save 4% on repair and maintenance costs.

Making your next car an EV is just one way to reduce your carbon footprint and work toward a cleaner, cooler future. Continue your energy-efficient conversion with induction stoves, heat pumps, and solar panel installation. Going solar can reduce your energy bill to as little as $0.

A home charging station powered by solar further reduces your EV charging costs, and EnergySage — a TCD-vetted source — can easily provide quotes from local installers and help you save up to $10,000 on solar installation.

Due to the upfront investment, buying a home solar system may not be possible for everyone, but leasing solar panels is an alternative for those looking to avoid high, fluctuating energy prices while also helping the planet.

Click your choice to see results and speak your mind.

Palmetto's LightReach solar panel leasing program installs panels with no money down and lets users lock in low energy rates. Upgrading your HVAC system to a heat pump can boost your solar power savings and help you pocket about $400 a year in energy costs.

For those in the market for a heat pump, Mitsubishi can help you find the right, affordable one for your home.

Other Redditors could relate to the original poster's mobile issue, as one shared, "I have to take my phone out of it's case [in] order to wirelessly charge it."

Another added, "The USB-C charging ports were put in the absolute worst spot. I've started using the rear ones and just running the cable up onto the passenger seat."

title: EU Unveils €2.9 Billion Green Fuel Initiative - Nautical Voice
description:
The European Commission has announced a significant €2.9 billion investment plan aimed at boosting sustainable fuel production for aviation and maritime transport by 2027.
The Commission emphasizes that achieving the EU’s climate goals will require a substantial increase in the availability of sustainable fuels, estimating a need for around 20 million tonnes by 2035.
Similarly, the aviation sector is expected to source 20% of its fuel from sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) by 2035, with a specific mandate for synthetic fuels known as e-SAF.
He emphasized the importance of translating the Sustainable Transport Investment Plan into concrete measures that will help bridge the cost gap between renewable marine fuels and traditional fossil fuels.
Without such measures, the uptake of sustainable fuels may stall, undermining the significant investments already made in the shipping sector.
text:
The European Commission has announced a significant €2.9 billion investment plan aimed at boosting sustainable fuel production for aviation and maritime transport by 2027. This initiative comes as the EU grapples with the challenge of decarbonizing heavy transport, which currently accounts for approximately 26.4% of emissions in the transport sector. With a binding climate goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2050, the urgency to transition to greener alternatives has never been more pressing.

Investment Goals and Challenges Ahead

The European Commission’s new plan is designed to accelerate the development of renewable and low-carbon fuels, which are essential for reducing carbon dioxide emissions from commercial aviation and shipping. Despite existing EU legislation aimed at promoting climate neutrality in these sectors, both remain heavily reliant on fossil fuels. The Commission emphasizes that achieving the EU’s climate goals will require a substantial increase in the availability of sustainable fuels, estimating a need for around 20 million tonnes by 2035. This ambitious target is projected to necessitate an investment of approximately €100 billion.

Commissioner for Sustainable Transport and Tourism, Apostolos Tzitzikostas, stated, “The package is about strengthening Europe’s competitiveness while moving decisively towards a net-zero future.” The funding will be drawn from the EU’s multiannual budget, which runs until 2027, and aims to support innovative technologies in renewable fuel production. Under current EU regulations, the maritime sector is required to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 2% starting in 2025, with a target of an 80% reduction in GHG intensity by 2050. Similarly, the aviation sector is expected to source 20% of its fuel from sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) by 2035, with a specific mandate for synthetic fuels known as e-SAF.

Industry Reactions and Future Prospects

While the Commission’s plan has been welcomed by various stakeholders, challenges remain in scaling up the production of sustainable fuels. Currently, over 40 e-fuel production projects are in the planning stages within the EU, but none have yet reached a final investment decision. Issues such as the availability and cost of renewable energy, carbon capture technologies, and the energy intensity required for producing green hydrogen are significant hurdles that need to be addressed.

Feedstock availability and aviation demand challenge biofuel adoption in shipping

Ourania Georgoutsakou, managing director of the aviation lobby group Airlines for Europe (A4E), highlighted the importance of reducing costs associated with sustainable aviation fuel to ensure air travel remains accessible. Meanwhile, Antony Froggatt from the campaign group Transport & Environment (T&E) expressed optimism about the Commission’s commitment to e-fuels but cautioned against the potential drawbacks of relying on biofuels. He stressed the need for a clear focus on e-fuels to ensure the success of the upcoming European Hydrogen Bank auction, which will allocate €300 million for aviation and maritime projects.

Jim Corbett, environmental director at the World Shipping Council, described the Commission’s initiative as a promising first step towards accelerating the energy transition in shipping. He emphasized the importance of translating the Sustainable Transport Investment Plan into concrete measures that will help bridge the cost gap between renewable marine fuels and traditional fossil fuels. Without such measures, the uptake of sustainable fuels may stall, undermining the significant investments already made in the shipping sector.

title: Elessent Clean Technologies on the Sulphurnet Acquisition Sulphuric Acid Market - ChemAnalyst
description:
Complete Interview with Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan Q: Please provide an overview of your professional journey and leadership experience in the chemicals, sulfur processing, and clean technologies sectors.
Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: The Sulphurnet acquisition strengthens Elessent’s global position by adding to our portfolio of solutions for our customers.
Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Elessent is leveraging Sulphurnet’s advanced filtration technology to enhance efficiency, safety, and sustainability in sulfur processing operations.
Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Elessent has established a dedicated integration team composed of both technical and functional experts from across the organization.
Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Sulphurnet was a great first acquisition for us.
text:
ChemAnalyst Talks with Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan, CEO of Elessent Clean Technologies

Elessent Clean Technologies, a global leader in process technologies, is driving sustainability and carbon neutrality across the metal, fertilizer, chemical, and oil refining sectors through its MECS® sulfuric acid, STRATCO® alkylation, BELCO® wet scrubbing, and IsoTherming® hydroprocessing solutions. ChemAnalyst spoke with Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan, CEO of Elessent Clean Technologies, about the strategic acquisition of Sulphurnet and how its advanced filtration technologies strengthen Elessent’s portfolio, enhance process reliability, and support the company’s mission to deliver cleaner, more efficient, and sustainable industrial solutions worldwide.

Complete Interview with Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan

Q: Please provide an overview of your professional journey and leadership experience in the chemicals, sulfur processing, and clean technologies sectors. How have these experiences shaped your strategic vision at Elessent Clean Technologies in driving innovation and sustainability across industrial processes?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: I’ve had the privilege of wearing many hats throughout my career, working across a wide range of industries, including refining, chemicals, polymers, biotechnology, and engineering. Each experience has shaped how I view industrial transformation and sustainability.

My passion for clean technologies really took root during my time with Genencor and later DuPont, which acquired Genencor in 2012. At Genencor, I saw how biotechnology could be leveraged to create sustainable alternatives to traditional chemical and polymerization processes. That realization fundamentally changed how I think about innovation and its role in enabling a cleaner industrial future.

When I transitioned from the biotechnology side of DuPont to the engineering side with DuPont Clean Technologies (DCT), now Elessent Clean Technologies, it gave me a new perspective. I learned how traditional industrial processes can be made cleaner and more energy-efficient without adding prohibitive costs. That bridge between biotechnology and engineering helped shape my belief that sustainability and performance are not mutually exclusive — they can, and should, advance together.

At Elessent, I’ve worked closely with our team to continue expanding our emission reduction and energy-efficiency initiatives. Some of the technologies I’m particularly proud of include our next-generation regenerative sulfuric acid systems that virtually eliminate emissions; mist elimination technology that supports green hydrogen production; value-engineered heat recovery systems that make energy efficiency viable in developing regions; scrubbing solutions adapted for carbon capture; and novel hydroprocessing technologies that enable the production of sustainable aviation fuel.

These experiences have reinforced my core belief: industrial progress and environmental responsibility can, and must, go hand in hand. At Elessent, that’s the vision guiding everything we do as we help industries around the world transition to a cleaner, more sustainable future.

Q: What strategic factors led Elessent to acquire Sulphurnet, and how does this acquisition align with your long-term growth and technology expansion plans?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Sulphurnet is a specialist in advanced industrial filtration and sulfur processing: it offers tailored systems (pressure-leaf filters, self-cleaning candle filters, modular sulfur-melting & purification plants) designed for demanding process environments. Elessent’s core portfolio already includes process technologies for sulfuric acid production, alkylation, wet scrubbing, hydroprocessing, and other downstream chemical/metal/oil refining sectors.

By acquiring Sulphurnet, Elessent is able to integrate a highly specialized filtration and purification capability that complements and deepens its existing technology stack. This portfolio extension helps Elessent address a wider set of process needs from filtering sulfur feed streams to fully purifying and modularizing plant solutions.

The acquisition expands Elessent’s addressable market. Filtration and purification are relevant across sulfuric acid, chemical plants, chlorine, hydrogen, fertilizer, mining/metal processing and beyond. Sulphurnet already serves multiple industries (e.g., metal/mineral, edible oil, amine filtration) in addition to its sulfur business. Elessent can cross-sell its existing technologies into the customer base that Sulphurnet brings, and vice versa, unlocking growth opportunities.

Q: Sulphurnet specializes in advanced filtration and sulfur impurity removal technologies. Could you elaborate on how these capabilities complement Elessent’s existing portfolio across sulfuric acid, chemical, chlorine, and green hydrogen sectors?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Sulphurnet’s advanced filtration and impurity-removal capabilities fill a critical upstream gap in Elessent’s portfolio. It means Elessent can offer not just the process technology (e.g., sulfuric acid, chlor-alkali, hydrogen) but also the essential feed/purification modules that ensure that the plant runs reliably, efficiently, and with less risk. For customers, that translates into higher uptime, better product quality, lower maintenance cost, and stronger environmental performance, all of which reinforce Elessent’s value proposition in its target markets.

Q: How does integrating Sulphurnet’s technologies enhance operational efficiency, reliability, and sustainability for Elessent’s customers in critical industrial processes?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Sulphurnet’s filters remove impurities like ash and fine solids from molten sulfur, so downstream units like sulfuric acid converters and boilers run much smoother. That means less fouling, reduced pressure drop, and better overall performance. With built-in monitoring tools like turbidity analyzers and flowmeters, operators can make real-time adjustments and avoid unplanned shutdowns.

By keeping the feed clean, we reduce catalyst fouling and blockages, which extends run lengths and cuts maintenance costs. Sulphurnet’s modular and automated filter systems are also built to handle tough environments, adding a layer of protection that keeps the rest of the process running reliably.

Q: In what ways does the acquisition strengthen Elessent’s competitive position globally, and how will it influence your market expansion strategy in Europe and other key regions?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: The Sulphurnet acquisition strengthens Elessent’s global position by adding to our portfolio of solutions for our customers. We recognize that customers can have problems in their acid plants due to upstream impurities, and we want to provide that solution as part of our suite of reliability and performance enhancers for new plans and throughout the life of the plant.

Q: Filtration and impurity removal are critical for optimizing sulfur processing. How does Elessent plan to leverage Sulphurnet’s technology to drive innovation and address emerging environmental and regulatory challenges in the chemical industry?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Elessent is leveraging Sulphurnet’s advanced filtration technology to enhance efficiency, safety, and sustainability in sulfur processing operations. A key focus is the adoption of Self-Cleaning Candle Filters (SCCF) to replace traditional pressure leaf filters in sulfur plants.

Unlike conventional systems, SCCFs automate the cleaning process, eliminating the need for operators to open filter housings or manually remove filter cakes. This design reduces exposure risks, minimizes emissions, and supports compliance with tightening environmental and occupational safety regulations.

By integrating Sulphurnet’s technology, Elessent is delivering solutions that mitigate EHS risk, improve process reliability, and reduce total operating costs. This collaboration reflects Elessent’s broader strategy to drive innovation in clean technologies, helping customers meet evolving regulatory demands while advancing toward more sustainable, low-emission operations.

Q: What synergies are expected between Elessent and Sulphurnet in terms of R&D, product development, and commercial deployment of advanced process technologies?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: We see tremendous opportunity in combining Elessent’s process expertise with Sulphurnet’s specialized filtration capabilities to accelerate innovation across our shared markets. Together, we’re focused on optimizing existing process technologies and expanding our strengths in emission control, corrosion prevention, and energy efficiency, areas that have long defined our solutions.

Through close collaboration in product development and commercial deployment, particularly with our Brink® mist eliminator group, we plan to bring the same level of customer focus and technical excellence to the filtration needs of these processes. By aligning our capabilities, we can deliver more integrated, sustainable, and efficient solutions that help our customers meet evolving environmental and operational challenges.

Q: During the integration of Sulphurnet, what operational or organizational challenges do you anticipate, and what measures are being implemented to ensure a smooth transition for customers and partners?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Elessent has established a dedicated integration team composed of both technical and functional experts from across the organization. This team has been meeting weekly for several months, first to conduct detailed planning and preparation, and now to track progress against defined objectives and make refinements as needed. The integration roadmap was developed collaboratively and is supported by clear governance and communication channels to maintain alignment between all parties.

Because of this extensive upfront planning and structured execution approach, we do not foresee any disruptions or challenges for customers or partners. Our focus remains on maintaining seamless operations, continuity of service, and a unified experience across both organizations throughout the integration process.

Q: Looking ahead, does Elessent plan to replicate similar acquisitions or partnerships to expand its technological capabilities in the clean technology and green hydrogen sectors?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Sulphurnet was a great first acquisition for us. From the very beginning, it was clear that we shared the same philosophy and vision: a strong focus on technology leadership, robustness, and putting the customer at the center of everything we do. That alignment has made the integration process very natural, and we’ve already identified a number of joint opportunities where our combined expertise adds real value for our customers.

The success we’ve seen with Sulphurnet reinforces my belief that this type of strategic, bolt-on acquisition is the right path forward for Elessent. When you find partners that complement your strengths, share your commitment to innovation, and are driven by the same customer-centric mindset, it creates tremendous potential for growth.

Q: Is Elessent leveraging digital tools, market intelligence, or advanced analytics to optimize process efficiency, monitor industry trends, and maximize the impact of Sulphurnet’s technologies across global operations?

Mr. Eli Ben-Shoshan: Elessent is in the early stages of integrating Sulphurnet’s technologies into our global platform, and while it is still too soon to point to specific digital tools or analytics systems being deployed, the integration process is strategically focused on building organizational readiness and alignment, specifically, by educating Elessent’s global sales network on Sulphurnet’s full suite of offerings. This ensures that our commercial teams across all regions are equipped to introduce Sulphurnet’s advanced sulfur filtration and separation solutions to sulfuric acid producers worldwide.

At the same time, we are working to integrate Sulphurnet’s engineering and design expertise into Elessent’s broader technology and project-execution platforms. This integration is critical for establishing a unified foundation that will later support the application of digital tools, process optimization models, and analytics capabilities across global operations. By embedding these designs into Elessent’s systems, we can streamline implementation, ensure global consistency, and create the data visibility needed to identify optimization and performance-enhancement opportunities over time.

ChemAnalyst Insights on Sulphuric Acid

title: НПЗ Казахстана готовы в кратчайшие сроки перейти на выпуск авиатоплива Jet A-1
description:
В Министерстве энергетики Казахстана прошла встреча вице-министра Кайырхана Туткышбаева с директором Европейского и Североатлантического регионального бюро ИКАО Николя Ралло.
Министерство энергетики заинтересовано в реализации проекта по производству устойчивого авиационного топлива совместно с американской компанией LanzaJet.
Кайырхан Туткышбаев сообщил, что отечественные нефтеперерабатывающие заводы готовы в кратчайшие сроки перейти на производство авиатоплива марки Jet A-1.
Кроме того, в настоящее время реализуются проекты по увеличению производства авиатоплива на отечественных заводах до 1,7 млн тонн в период 2026–2032 годов.
SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel) еще называют «устойчивое авиационное топливо».
text:
В Министерстве энергетики Казахстана прошла встреча вице-министра Кайырхана Туткышбаева с директором Европейского и Североатлантического регионального бюро ИКАО Николя Ралло.

В ходе беседы стороны обсудили перспективы сотрудничества в сфере устойчивого развития авиационной отрасли, включая вопросы внедрения и производства более экологичного авиационного топлива SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel) в Казахстане.

Вице-министр отметил, что Казахстан активно участвует в «зеленой» трансформации, делая акцент на развитие возобновляемых источников энергии и экологически устойчивых проектов. Развитие и производство такого авиационного топлива станет «важной частью сокращения выбросов парниковых газов в авиационном секторе Казахстана».

Министерство энергетики заинтересовано в реализации проекта по производству устойчивого авиационного топлива совместно с американской компанией LanzaJet.

Кайырхан Туткышбаев сообщил, что отечественные нефтеперерабатывающие заводы готовы в кратчайшие сроки перейти на производство авиатоплива марки Jet A-1. Кроме того, в настоящее время реализуются проекты по увеличению производства авиатоплива на отечественных заводах до 1,7 млн тонн в период 2026–2032 годов. Сейчас в стране выпускают до 750 млн тонн авиатоплива.

SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel) еще называют «устойчивое авиационное топливо». Оно производится из возобновляемых ресурсов, таких как отработанное кухонное масло, растительные остатки или уловленный CO2. Оно сокращает выбросы парниковых газов в течение жизненного цикла продукта. Технологически SAF считается более экологичным и чистым заменителем ископаемого керосина.

title: Sea-Tac, Delta aim to use more sustainable fuel. Will that help potential Longview company?
description:
The industry looked to sustainable aviation fuel, a type of jet fuel made from organic materials such as greases, food scraps and yard waste.
It’s still unclear if Northwest Advanced Bio-Fuels’ sustainable aviation fuel effort will be the project to break through.
The Trump administration, meanwhile, has extended Biden-era tax credits for sustainable aviation fuel production and supported at least one Northwest project.
Production goals Locally, Sea-Tac airport officials say they will power every flight fueled there with at least a 10 percent locally produced sustainable aviation fuel by 2028.
Delta, for its part, also has maintained its goal to use 10 percent sustainable aviation fuel by 2030.
text:
After a nearly 45-year career in tech and infrastructure and trying his hand in wind and other renewable energy technologies, Dave Smoot pivoted to sustainable aviation fuels in the 2010s.

His timing could not have been better.

Sustainability was the hot concept across the corporate world as consumers became increasingly aware of climate change.

Aviation insiders worried that headlines about the public’s concerns about the climate impacts of flying — which contributes to about 2.5 percent of global greenhouse gas emission each year — would soon hurt airlines’ profits.

The industry looked to sustainable aviation fuel, a type of jet fuel made from organic materials such as greases, food scraps and yard waste.

In Smoot’s case, the fuel would be made from the wood byproducts of the timber and mill industries. He even had a planned partnership in 2019 to provide the fuel to Delta, which Delta recently confirmed is active.

While he has locked his sights on the Port of Longview’s Barlow Point, Smoot’s project still must secure tens of millions in development capital investment to determine if the site will work — and he has to do it before the political winds change.

Clean energy future

“Out of 100 projects, a very tiny percentage come to fruition,” said Neil Maunu, who runs the powerful, Vancouver-based Pacific Northwest Waterways Association trade group comprised of ports, businesses and public agencies looking to stimulate economic development on the region’s waterways.

It’s still unclear if Northwest Advanced Bio-Fuels’ sustainable aviation fuel effort will be the project to break through. And current events don’t offer much clarity.

An August investigation by Reuters found airlines have announced 165 sustainable aviation fuel projects in the past dozen years, but only 36 have materialized.

“Reuters found that the airline industry’s plans to go green before regulators start penalizing them are little more than a pipe dream,” it concluded.

Clean energy projects also have been killed en masse during the second Trump administration.

President Donald Trump has successfully pushed many of the country’s larger companies to abandon their climate goals, including some airlines.

And Delta’s CEO has signaled his support for the Trump administration.

Yet both Delta and Trump’s actions defy simple explanations.

Delta has criticized some administration policies, and a company spokesperson confirmed to The Daily News that it is maintaining its climate goals.

The Trump administration, meanwhile, has extended Biden-era tax credits for sustainable aviation fuel production and supported at least one Northwest project.

And Washington has its own incentives, creating a particularly favorable environment for these kinds of energy projects.

Ultimately, demand for the fuel and the economic forces driving it may be the deciding factor in the commodity’s future.

Airlines already have started to face fines in Europe for not meeting ecological goals.

Production goals

Locally, Sea-Tac airport officials say they will power every flight fueled there with at least a 10 percent locally produced sustainable aviation fuel by 2028. A spokesperson for the airport said almost none of the 600 million gallons of jet fuel used at the facility each year is from sustainable sourcing right now.

But the goal stands, Perry Cooper, media relations manager for the airport, said by email.

“We’ve done the studies on how to get (the fuel) here but, no, there is not a supplier here yet,” he wrote.

Sea-Tac is a regional hub for Delta and one of the airports Smoot said would use his fuel.

Delta, for its part, also has maintained its goal to use 10 percent sustainable aviation fuel by 2030.

title: Kazakhstan eyes production of sustainable aviation fuel - Kazinform
description:
According to the Ministry’s press service, the sides discussed prospects for cooperation in promoting sustainable development in the aviation sector, including the adoption and production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Kazakhstan.
The Deputy Minister noted that Kazakhstan is actively advancing its green transformation, focusing on the development of renewable energy sources and environmentally sustainable projects.
The Ministry of Energy is interested in implementing a SAF production project in partnership with the U.S.-based company LanzaJet.
Tutkyshbayev stated that domestic oil refineries are ready to begin producing Jet A-1 aviation fuel in the near future.
Moreover, large-scale projects are underway to increase aviation fuel production capacity at local refineries to 1.7 million tons between 2026 and 2032.
text:
According to the Ministry’s press service, the sides discussed prospects for cooperation in promoting sustainable development in the aviation sector, including the adoption and production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Kazakhstan.

The Deputy Minister noted that Kazakhstan is actively advancing its green transformation, focusing on the development of renewable energy sources and environmentally sustainable projects. He emphasized that the development and production of SAF would play a key role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions in Kazakhstan’s aviation industry.

The Ministry of Energy is interested in implementing a SAF production project in partnership with the U.S.-based company LanzaJet.

Tutkyshbayev stated that domestic oil refineries are ready to begin producing Jet A-1 aviation fuel in the near future.

Moreover, large-scale projects are underway to increase aviation fuel production capacity at local refineries to 1.7 million tons between 2026 and 2032.

According to the Ministry’s press service, the sides discussed prospects for cooperation in promoting sustainable development in the aviation sector, including the adoption and production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Kazakhstan, The Caspian Post reports citing Kazinform.

The Deputy Minister noted that Kazakhstan is actively advancing its green transformation, focusing on the development of renewable energy sources and environmentally sustainable projects. He emphasized that the development and production of SAF would play a key role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions in Kazakhstan’s aviation industry.

The Ministry of Energy is interested in implementing a SAF production project in partnership with the U.S.-based company LanzaJet.

Tutkyshbayev stated that domestic oil refineries are ready to begin producing Jet A-1 aviation fuel in the near future.

Moreover, large-scale projects are underway to increase aviation fuel production capacity at local refineries to 1.7 million tons between 2026 and 2032.

text:
Renewable Aviation Fuel Market Overview:

The Renewable Aviation Fuel Market Size was valued at 4,330 USD Million in 2024. The Renewable Aviation Fuel Market is expected to grow from 5.16 USD Billion in 2025 to 30 USD Billion by 2035. The Renewable Aviation Fuel Market CAGR (growth rate) is expected to be around 19.2% during the forecast period (2025 - 2035).

The global aviation industry has been under increasing pressure to reduce its carbon footprint and embrace more sustainable practices. With air travel accounting for a significant portion of global greenhouse gas emissions, the adoption of renewable aviation fuel (RAF) has emerged as a critical solution. Renewable aviation fuels, derived from sustainable feedstocks such as algae, waste oils, and agricultural residues, offer an environmentally friendly alternative to conventional jet fuels while maintaining the performance standards required for commercial and military aviation.

The market for renewable aviation fuel is rapidly gaining traction as airlines, governments, and environmental agencies collaborate to achieve carbon neutrality targets. Key stakeholders are investing in production technologies, feedstock diversification, and large-scale adoption strategies to ensure that the transition to cleaner aviation fuel is both economically viable and scalable.

Get Free Sample PDF Brochure: https://www.wiseguyreports.com/sample-request?id=684941

Market Dynamics

Renewable aviation fuel, often referred to as sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), has the potential to reduce life-cycle carbon emissions by up to 80% compared to traditional jet fuels. This significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions has positioned RAF as a strategic solution in the fight against climate change. Moreover, government regulations and international commitments, such as the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA), are encouraging airlines to adopt renewable fuels.

The market is further driven by collaborations between fuel producers and airlines to establish supply chains capable of supporting large-scale fuel distribution. Regional production hubs are emerging, leveraging locally available feedstocks to reduce logistical costs and enhance fuel availability.

Market Drivers and Growth Factors

Several key factors are propelling the growth of the renewable aviation fuel market. One of the primary drivers is the global push for sustainability and the reduction of carbon emissions in the aviation sector. Airlines are increasingly under pressure from environmental groups, investors, and regulatory bodies to adopt cleaner energy solutions. Renewable aviation fuel offers a viable pathway to meet these environmental objectives without compromising on fuel efficiency and aircraft performance.

Technological advancements in fuel production, including hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids (HEFA) and Fischer-Tropsch processes, have enabled the production of high-quality RAF that meets stringent aviation standards. Additionally, economies of scale and government incentives, such as tax credits and subsidies for sustainable fuel production, are encouraging investments in this sector.

Buy Now Premium Research Report: https://www.wiseguyreports.com/checkout?currency=one_user-USD&report_id=684941

Technological Advancements and Innovations

Innovation plays a critical role in the renewable aviation fuel market. New processing techniques, such as catalytic conversion and advanced bio-refining, are enhancing fuel yield, efficiency, and cost-effectiveness. Research institutions and commercial enterprises are actively exploring feedstock diversification, including the use of algae, municipal solid waste, and agricultural residues. These innovations not only increase the availability of renewable feedstocks but also minimize competition with food crops, addressing a key sustainability concern.

Furthermore, blending renewable fuels with conventional jet fuel has proven to be an effective strategy to reduce emissions without requiring modifications to existing aircraft engines. Such hybrid approaches allow airlines to gradually transition to higher renewable fuel ratios, supporting both environmental goals and operational feasibility.

Regional Insights

The renewable aviation fuel market is witnessing significant regional variations in adoption and production capacity. North America and Europe are leading markets due to stringent environmental regulations, strong government incentives, and the presence of major fuel producers. In the United States, several initiatives promote the commercialization of SAF, including federal grants and partnerships with airlines to integrate renewable fuels into commercial flights.

Asia-Pacific is emerging as a promising market, driven by increasing air traffic, environmental awareness, and government support for green aviation. Countries like China and Japan are actively investing in local production facilities and research projects to reduce dependency on fossil-based jet fuels. Similarly, Latin America is exploring opportunities to produce RAF from sugarcane, palm oil residues, and other biomass feedstocks, positioning the region as a potential growth hub in the coming years.

Browse In-depth Market Research Report: https://www.wiseguyreports.com/reports/renewable-aviation-fuel-market

Competitive Landscape

The renewable aviation fuel market is moderately competitive, with several key players vying for market share through strategic collaborations, mergers, and technology licensing agreements. Major fuel producers, bio-refineries, and airlines are forming partnerships to ensure a stable supply of renewable fuels and meet increasing demand.

Companies are also investing in research and development to improve production efficiency, reduce costs, and explore new feedstock options. Collaborations with governments and international organizations are common, enabling stakeholders to leverage subsidies, grants, and favorable policy frameworks to scale operations. Additionally, industry alliances are fostering standardization and certification processes, ensuring that renewable aviation fuels meet the rigorous safety and quality requirements of the aviation sector.

Challenges and Restraints

Despite its promising growth, the renewable aviation fuel market faces several challenges. High production costs remain a primary restraint, limiting the widespread adoption of renewable fuels. Feedstock availability and competition with other bio-based industries also pose significant challenges, especially in regions with limited agricultural resources.

Infrastructure constraints, including storage, blending, and distribution capabilities, further hinder market growth. Airlines must navigate complex supply chains to secure a consistent supply of renewable fuels, and existing airport fuel infrastructure often requires upgrades to handle large-scale adoption. Nevertheless, continued investments in research, policy support, and technological innovation are expected to address these challenges over time.

Future Outlook

The future of renewable aviation fuel looks promising, with market expansion expected across all major regions. Increasing investments in sustainable production methods, policy incentives, and growing environmental awareness are anticipated to drive substantial growth. As airlines seek to meet carbon reduction targets and improve operational sustainability, RAF adoption is likely to become a standard practice in the aviation sector.

In the long term, technological advancements, combined with collaborative efforts between governments, fuel producers, and airlines, will enable the industry to achieve higher fuel efficiency, reduced emissions, and a more resilient supply chain. The integration of renewable aviation fuel into mainstream aviation operations represents a significant step toward a sustainable and environmentally responsible aviation industry.

title: EPA grants full/partial approvals for 14 additional SRE petitions, denies 2 petitions
description:
The agency granted full exemptions to two petitions, partial (50%) exemptions to 12 petitions, and denied two petitions.
For an SRE petition to be approved, the refiner must demonstrate “disproportionate economic hardship” in satisfying its RVO requirements.
As part of the SRE application process, the U.S. Department of Energy is tasked with analyzing and scoring SRE petitions.
There are now 15 SRE petitions pending, including two filed for RFS compliance year 2023, one for RFS compliance year 2024 and 12 for RFS compliance year 2025.
The Nov. 7 action on 16 SRE petitions follows the EPA’s Aug. 22 decisions on 175 SRE petitions filed by 38 small refineries for compliance years 2016-2024.
text:
SOURCE: U.S. EPA

November 7, 2025

BY Erin Krueger

The U.S. EPA on Nov. 7 issued decisions on 16 small refinery exemption (SRE) petitions filed by eight small refineries. The agency granted full exemptions to two petitions, partial (50%) exemptions to 12 petitions, and denied two petitions.

The SRE program allows eligible small refiners, defined as those that process no more than 75,000 barrels per day of crude oil, to petition the EPA seeking exemptions of their Renewable Fuel Standard renewable volume requirements (RVOs) for a given RFS compliance year.

For an SRE petition to be approved, the refiner must demonstrate “disproportionate economic hardship” in satisfying its RVO requirements. As part of the SRE application process, the U.S. Department of Energy is tasked with analyzing and scoring SRE petitions. The EPA, however, makes the final determination to approve or deny each petition.

According to information released by the EPA, the agency has fully approved one SRE petition for RFS compliance year 2023 and one for RFS compliance year 2024. The 50% partial approvals include four for compliance year 2021, two for compliance year 2022, four for compliance year 2023, and two for compliance year 2024. The two denials include one each for compliance year 2023 and 2024.

On a combined basis, the approvals have reduced the total RVO for all four years by 740 million renewable identification numbers (RINs). This includes 150 million RINs for 2021, 70 million RINs for 2022, 250 million RINs for 2023 and 260 million RINs for 2024.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The EPA also updated its online SRE data dashboard, showing one new SRE petition has been filed since mid-October. That petition, filed by Kern Oil & Refining Co., seeks a waiver of the 2025 RVOs for its facility in Bakersfield, California.

There are now 15 SRE petitions pending, including two filed for RFS compliance year 2023, one for RFS compliance year 2024 and 12 for RFS compliance year 2025.

The Nov. 7 action on 16 SRE petitions follows the EPA’s Aug. 22 decisions on 175 SRE petitions filed by 38 small refineries for compliance years 2016-2024. In that action, the EPA granted full exemptions to 63 petitions, granted partial (50%) exemptions to 77 petitions, denied 28 petitions and determined 7 petitions to be ineligible.

In documentation released Nov. 7, the EPA issued a correction to its Aug. 22 action, noting it “erroneously provided a partial exemption for the 2020 compliance year to a small refinery that should have been provided a full exemption.” The agency attributed the mistake to a clerical error made by DOE in transcribing the metric from the scoring rationale to the DOE matrix. To correct the error, the EPA has changed the partial approval for that SRE application to a full approval.

As part of its Nov. 7 announcement, the EPA said it is reaffirming the agency’s policy of returning RINs previously retired for compliance when a small refinery receives an exemption for a prior compliance year. While no actual RINs will be returned today, EPA said will follow standard agency policy and instruct those impacted to contact the EPA Fuels Program Helpdesk to initiate the RINs return process.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Moving forward, the EPA said it is committed to ruling on SRE applications within the statutory 90-day review period.

The agency also briefly addressed the supplemental notice of proposed rulemaking (SNPRM) it issued in September that addresses how the agency plans to reallocate waived SRE volumes moving forward. The comment period on that SNRPM closed Oct. 31. In its Nov. 7 announcement, the EPA said it “is reviewing comments on the supplemental proposed rule as the agency continues to work on final regulations for the “Set 2” rule. As stated in the SNPRM, EPA intends to update the agency’s projections of exempted gasoline and diesel volumes in the final rule based on any additional SREs issued after the proposal, including the petition decisions in this action.”

The Renewable Fuels Association criticized the EPA’s new SRE approvals. “Today, EPA created even more uncertainty and confusion in the renewable fuel and agriculture markets, which are already under immense pressure from record corn and soybean harvests this fall,” said Geoff Cooper, president and CEO of the RFA. “EPA added another 14 small refinery exemptions to the already-massive pile today, based on the agency’s questionable new approach to determining whether those refiners experienced ‘disproportionate economic hardship.’ We continue to dispute the notion that SREs are warranted at all, as EPA’s own analysis shows that all refiners—large and small—face a proportional RFS compliance obligation and pass their RIN costs through to buyers of their refined products. The silver lining here is that EPA is returning expired RINs to the six refineries who were granted exemptions from their 2021 and 2022 RFS obligations. However, more than 500 million valid RINs will be issued to eight refineries who were gifted exemptions from their 2023 and 2024 obligations, meaning there are now more than 2.5 billion RINs associated with 2023-2025 SREs that are likely to be dropped back onto the market in the months ahead. If EPA fails to reallocate those volumes when it finalizes the 2026 and 2027 RVOs, the impact on biofuel and agriculture markets will be devastating. Today’s decision further underscores the crucial need for EPA to finalize 2026-2027 RVOs that fully reallocate any and all SREs granted, or expected to be granted, for the 2023-2027 compliance years.”

The EPA in late 2022 began publishing basic data on the each SRE petition filed with the agency, including company name, location and compliance year. A full copy of that data is available below.

title: United States Biodiesel Market: Powering America's Green Fuel Revolution - Vocal Media
description:
As industries, governments, and consumers shift away from high-carbon fossil fuels, the biodiesel market is gaining momentum at scale—backed by policy support, environmental urgency, and technological innovation.
According to Renub Research, the United States Biodiesel Market is projected to reach US$ 20.29 billion by 2033, rising from US$ 12.23 billion in 2024, registering a CAGR of 5.79% from 2025 to 2033.
Unlike petroleum-based diesel, biodiesel dramatically lowers greenhouse gas emissions and can be used in standard diesel engines either in pure form (B100) or blended with petroleum diesel (B5, B20).
In 2023, Be8 entered the U.S. biofuel market to scale ethanol and renewable fuel technologies, underscoring industry confidence in technological transformation.
With increasing private-sector sustainability mandates, the fuel application segment dominates U.S. biodiesel demand.
text:
The United States is accelerating toward a greener energy future, and biodiesel has firmly positioned itself as one of the country’s clean fuel cornerstones. As industries, governments, and consumers shift away from high-carbon fossil fuels, the biodiesel market is gaining momentum at scale—backed by policy support, environmental urgency, and technological innovation.

According to Renub Research, the United States Biodiesel Market is projected to reach US$ 20.29 billion by 2033, rising from US$ 12.23 billion in 2024, registering a CAGR of 5.79% from 2025 to 2033. This impressive growth is driven by a strong national push for renewable fuel adoption, expanding demand across transportation and power sectors, and growing investment in sustainable feedstock innovation.

What is Biodiesel and Why is America Betting Big on It?

Biodiesel is a renewable, biodegradable fuel produced from vegetable oils, animal fats, and recycled cooking grease. Unlike petroleum-based diesel, biodiesel dramatically lowers greenhouse gas emissions and can be used in standard diesel engines either in pure form (B100) or blended with petroleum diesel (B5, B20).

In the U.S., biodiesel adoption extends across:

Transportation (trucks, public transit, freight)

Agriculture (tractors, farm machinery)

Marine and industrial operations

Power generation

Residential and commercial heating (Bioheat®)

With federal and state governments pressing ahead with climate commitments and clean air directives, biodiesel has become central to America’s energy transition—promising lower emissions, higher energy security, and circular waste utilization.

Market Drivers Fueling U.S. Biodiesel Growth

✅ 1. Strong Government Policies & Renewable Fuel Standards (RFS)

The U.S. government has been instrumental in scaling biodiesel consumption through mandates and incentives, including:

Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) requiring biofuel blending

Biodiesel Tax Credit (BTC) to offset production costs

State-level clean fuel programs like California’s LCFS

In December 2023, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced RFS volume requirements for 2023-2025, strengthening biofuel incorporation into the national energy mix. These regulations ensure consistent demand, price support, and investment security for biodiesel producers.

✅ 2. Growing Demand for Low-Carbon & Sustainable Fuels

Corporate fleets, logistics providers, public transit networks, and agricultural operators are turning to biodiesel to meet sustainability goals. States such as California and Washington, which enforce aggressive emissions reduction policies, have become key consumption hubs.

Adding to this momentum, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) spotlighted sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) pathways, reinforcing bio-based fuels as a long-term decarbonization pillar.

✅ 3. Technological Advancements in Feedstock and Processing

Modern processing techniques like:

Transesterification

Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil (HVO) technology

Algae-based biofuel innovation

Waste-derived feedstock utilization

…are making biodiesel more cost-efficient, scalable, and engine-compatible. In 2023, Be8 entered the U.S. biofuel market to scale ethanol and renewable fuel technologies, underscoring industry confidence in technological transformation.

Barriers the Market Must Overcome

❌ Feedstock Price Volatility

Primary biodiesel feedstocks—such as soybean oil, canola, and animal fats—are vulnerable to:

Climate disruption

Crop yield fluctuations

Global commodity price volatility

Supply chain interruptions

These factors can destabilize production costs and challenge biodiesel’s competitiveness against conventional and renewable diesel.

❌ Increasing Competition from Emerging Alternatives

Biodiesel competes with:

Renewable diesel (chemically closer to petroleum diesel)

Electric vehicles (EVs)

Hydrogen fuel technologies

Though biodiesel leads in market adoption today, sustained innovation will be essential to preserve long-term demand.

Segment-Wise Market Insights

🚚 By Application: Fuel Leads the Market

Biodiesel is primarily utilized in:

Commercial fleets

Logistics and freight transport

Public transit systems

Blends like B20 have become popular as they balance emissions reduction without requiring engine modification. With increasing private-sector sustainability mandates, the fuel application segment dominates U.S. biodiesel demand.

🌾 By Feedstock: Vegetable Oil vs. Animal Fats

🟩 Vegetable Oil Biodiesel

Soybean, canola, and corn oils lead feedstock volume due to:

Strong domestic agriculture output

Established supply chains

Government-backed agri-biofuel incentives

However, price fluctuations tied to crop cycles remain an ongoing challenge.

🟧 Animal Fats Biodiesel

Tallow and used cooking grease are emerging as high-demand, low-cost feedstocks. This waste-to-energy approach:

Reduces landfill burden

Cuts production costs

Offers superior energy return

The animal fats segment is expected to grow rapidly as circular economy policies expand.

State-Level Biodiesel Market Highlights

🌟 California — The Undisputed Leader

Driven by:

Low Carbon Fuel Standard (LCFS)

Massive transportation and agricultural demand

Leadership in emissions goals

California remains the largest biodiesel consumption hub. In April 2022, BDI-BioEnergy International launched a state-of-the-art biodiesel plant in Bakersfield, further strengthening supply capacity.

🗽 New York — Bioheat® and Public Transit Adoption

With high population density and strong clean energy agendas, New York leads in:

Municipal fleet biodiesel adoption

Home heating biodiesel blends (Bioheat®)

Commercial and residential decarbonization initiatives

🌲 Washington — Renewable Fuel & Feedstock Growth

Washington benefits from:

Clean Fuel Standard (CFS)

Local feedstock availability (soybean, canola)

Strong seaport and logistics biodiesel demand

🚛 New Jersey — Strategic Logistics Advantage

Due to:

Proximity to major ports

Urban transportation demand

Supportive state policies for alternative fuels

New Jersey continues to expand biodiesel usage in municipal fleets and freight networks.

Market Segmentation Snapshot

By Application

Fuel

Power Generation

Others

By Feedstock

Vegetable Oil

Animal Fats

By Key States

California, Texas, New York, Florida, Illinois, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Georgia, New Jersey, Washington, North Carolina, Massachusetts, Virginia, Michigan, Maryland, Colorado, Tennessee, Indiana, Arizona, Minnesota, Wisconsin, Missouri, Connecticut, South Carolina, Oregon, Louisiana, Alabama, Kentucky + Rest of U.S.

Competitive Landscape

Major companies shaping market innovation and supply scalability include:

Company Market Edge

Archer Daniels Midland Company Feedstock supply strength & biofuel processing scale

FutureFuel Diversified biofuel refining solutions

Neste’s Global leadership in renewable diesel & biodiesel

Renewable Energy Group, Inc. One of the largest biodiesel producers in the U.S.

Bunge Global SA Strong agri-commodity integration

Wilmar Feedstock sourcing and processing scale

Shell Strategic energy transition investments

The Road Ahead: What’s Next for U.S. Biodiesel?

America’s biodiesel sector is evolving into a long-game infrastructure play driven by:

Climate targets and regulatory support

Expansion of sustainable feedstocks

Cost-competitive production technology

Corporate and industrial decarbonization strategies

As renewable fuels become mission-critical for national energy security and corporate ESG goals, biodiesel is emerging not just as a fuel alternative, but as a long-term energy mandate.

Final Thoughts

Biodiesel is no longer a niche energy solution—it is a strategic fuel powering America’s transportation, agriculture, and industrial future. With a forecasted market of US$ 20.29 billion by 2033, the U.S. is laying the foundation for a cleaner, carbon-responsible, and fuel-independent future.

For investors, policymakers, and ESG-driven enterprises, the biodiesel boom isn't coming—it's already here.

title: Биотопливо SAF для самолетов планирует производить Казахстан с компанией из США
description:
Кайырхан Туткышбаев отметил, что отечественные нефтеперерабатывающие заводы готовы в кратчайшие сроки перейти на производство авиатоплива марки Jet A-1.
Для чего переход на Jet A-1 Jet A-1 ‒ это традиционное ископаемое реактивное топливо, а Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) ‒ это альтернативное топливо из возобновляемых источников.
SAF разработан для замены Jet A-1, чтобы сделать перелёты более экологичными.
Почему это важно для экологии Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) ‒ это альтернативное экологически чистое авиационное топливо, производимое из возобновляемых источников, а не из нефти.
По данным International Council on Clean Transportation, устойчивое авиационное топливо (SAF) сейчас в 2-5 раз дороже обычного авиакеросина.
text:
Что произошло

Вице-министр энергетики Кайырхан Туткышбаев и директор Европейского и Североатлантического регионального бюро международной организации гражданской авиации (ИКАО) Николя Ралло обсудили вопросы внедрения и производства устойчивого авиационного топлива SAF (Sustainable Aviation Fuel) в Казахстане.

Что говорят в Минэнерго

В министерстве энергетики сообщили о заинтересованности в реализации проекта по производству устойчивого авиационного топлива совместно с американской компанией LanzaJet.

Кайырхан Туткышбаев отметил, что отечественные нефтеперерабатывающие заводы готовы в кратчайшие сроки перейти на производство авиатоплива марки Jet A-1.

В минэнерго также рассказали о планах увеличить с 2026 по 2032 год производство авиатоплива на казахстанских заводах до 1,7 млн тонн.

Для чего переход на Jet A-1

Jet A-1 ‒ это традиционное ископаемое реактивное топливо, а Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) ‒ это альтернативное топливо из возобновляемых источников. SAF разработан для замены Jet A-1, чтобы сделать перелёты более экологичными.

Почему это важно для экологии

Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) ‒ это альтернативное экологически чистое авиационное топливо, производимое из возобновляемых источников, а не из нефти.

Оно значительно снижает выбросы парниковых газов по сравнению с традиционным авиакеросином и может смешиваться с ним для использования в существующих самолетах без модификации двигателей.

SAF производится из различного сырья, такого как отработанные масла, сельскохозяйственные отходы, растительные и животные жиры, а также из спиртов и синтетических процессов.

Таким образом, Казахстан намерен сократить выбросы парниковых газов в отечественном авиационном секторе.

Что еще

Владелец международного аэропорта "Сары-Арка" в Караганде Ерлан Оспанов в интервью BES.media ранее отмечал, что решающее влияние на цену билетов вносят расходы на топливо, обслуживание самолётов и дефицит воздушных судов.

По данным International Council on Clean Transportation, устойчивое авиационное топливо (SAF) сейчас в 2-5 раз дороже обычного авиакеросина.

Кроме того, технологии производства биотоплива могут быть более сложными и дорогими. Поэтому все эти факторы могут повлиять на цену авиабилетов в сторону повышения.

title: 21 European Airlines Pledged to Stop Making Misleading "Greenwashing" Claims
authors: Helen William, Mahesh Darkunde, Natalia Shelley
description:
BRUSSELS– Around 21 European carriers have pledged to curb misleading environmental claims following rising scrutiny over airline “greenwashing”: Lufthansa (LH) and KLM (KL) are the most prominent names in this initiative.
21 European Airlines Commitments It has been reported that many carriers across Europe have historically marketed “green fares” or sustainable aviation fuel in ways passengers often misinterpreted as offsetting flight emissions directly.
Closer to the Implementation Measures Airlines will now conduct internal audits of all marketing material, including websites, booking platforms, and advertising campaigns, to ensure sustainability claims are fully accurate.
Bottom Line European airlines, including Lufthansa Group and KLM, are committing to transparent environmental claims just as the aviation sector accounts for roughly 2.5 % of global CO₂ emissions.
With mandates such as the ReFuelEU Aviation targeting up to 70 % usage of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by 2050, the industry is finally aligning its marketing with measurable decarbonisation goals.
text:
BRUSSELS– Around 21 European carriers have pledged to curb misleading environmental claims following rising scrutiny over airline “greenwashing”: Lufthansa (LH) and KLM (KL) are the most prominent names in this initiative.

This move comes as the European Union intensifies efforts to ensure passengers receive accurate information about airline sustainability, where the Consumer Protection Cooperation Network in the EU has launched a framework requiring airlines to clarify environmental claims.

21 European Airlines Commitments

It has been reported that many carriers across Europe have historically marketed “green fares” or sustainable aviation fuel in ways passengers often misinterpreted as offsetting flight emissions directly.

Therefore, twenty-one airlines have been asked to enhance transparency and avoid vague green terminology that could mislead customers.

Marketing language suggesting that purchasing a “green fare” directly neutralizes carbon emissions will no longer be permitted. The commitment is intended to prevent passengers from overestimating the environmental impact of individual flights.

Lufthansa and KLM, Air France, Finnair, and EasyJet have committed to clear communication about sustainability. Other signatories include Ryanair, Norwegian, TAP, SAS, SWISS, Brussels Airlines, Volotea, Vueling, Luxair, Eurowings, Air Dolomiti, Transavia, and Air Baltic.

Europe’s Greenwashing Concerns

For years, airlines have faced criticism for overstating their environmental efforts. Claims of sustainable fuel usage and carbon-neutral flights often lacked transparency and verifiable evidence.

Consumers have increasingly questioned the legitimacy of such statements, prompting regulatory oversight, with Paddle Your Own Kanoo reporting:

Airlines will now clearly differentiate between general sustainability initiatives and direct carbon offset programs. This distinction ensures that passengers understand that buying a ticket labeled “green” does not equate to a net reduction of emissions for their specific journey.

Closer to the Implementation Measures

Airlines will now conduct internal audits of all marketing material, including websites, booking platforms, and advertising campaigns, to ensure sustainability claims are fully accurate.

Compliance teams will verify that terms like “carbon-neutral flight” or “green fare” are only used when emissions offsets are fully traceable and verified.

Carrier websites and apps will include transparent sustainability reporting, showing data such as fleet fuel efficiency improvements, adoption rates of sustainable aviation fuels, and corporate carbon-reduction achievements.

Passengers will be able to see exactly what portion of emissions is offset and which initiatives contribute to the overall environmental impact.

Regulatory oversight will also require airlines to submit annual progress reports to the EU Consumer Protection Cooperation Network.

These reports must document how marketing language has been corrected, how passenger communications have improved, and what measurable reductions in carbon emissions the airline has achieved.

This ensures accountability and ongoing adherence to the greenwashing prevention framework.

Bottom Line

European airlines, including Lufthansa Group and KLM, are committing to transparent environmental claims just as the aviation sector accounts for roughly 2.5 % of global CO₂ emissions.

With mandates such as the ReFuelEU Aviation targeting up to 70 % usage of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) by 2050, the industry is finally aligning its marketing with measurable decarbonisation goals.

As a result, passengers can trust clearer, verifiable information on sustainable travel—and the carriers willing to lead are setting a bold new standard for the aviation industry’s integrity and future.

Stay tuned with us. Further, follow us on social media for the latest updates.
